intro: Calandrinia polycarpoides, commonly known as the mountain morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Portulacaceae family and is characterized by its succulent, fleshy stems and leaves. The plant produces showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that are typically pink or red, which bloom in the morning and close in the afternoon. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or arid environments. Calandrinia polycarpoides is adapted to withstand drought and high temperatures, making it a resilient species in its native habitat.
